body: @highend, have you managed to make it work somehow, or what’s your current workaround?
Nope, I've terminated my HiDrive contract :/

I tried it with webdav and the HiDrive service from ionos.com, because webdav is integrated in the cheaper accounts, for smb or rsync you have to pay extra. It worked like this:
```
rclone config create hidrive webdav url https://webdav.hidrive.ionos.com vendor other user myusername pass mypassword
rclone copy hidrive:users/myusername/test.txt .
```
With "myusername" your username as showed in "Settings" of the HiDrive web interface. This copied the file "test.txt" from HiDrive to my local system. Works with directories and for uploads as well.

Thanks for testing @Frank-Buss - that looks like a pretty standard WebDAV setup.

Is this worth writing up in the docs? How popular is HiDrive?

I don't know how popular it is. But searching for HiDrive in Google results in 490,000 pages, and it is pretty cheap with EUR 1 per month for the first 12 months for 100 GB. And apparently there is no additional transfer costs, like you have to pay for other services, e.g. Google Cloud storage. Might be useful to add it to the documentation. The "users/myusername" part and the URL was not obvious and I needed some time to find it out.

Do you want to have a go at adding it to the docs @Frank-Buss ? The file in question is this one

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/docs/content/webdav.md
Strato HiDrive is currently on sale: 1TB for 1€ for the first year.

> Strato HiDrive is currently on sale: 1TB for 1€ for the first year.

Not sure whether this is constantly the case, but atm they still/again advertise the same rate ("Easter Savings"), which also includes smb/rsync among other protocols. Apart from the domain name (`strato.com` instead of `ionos.com`), everything works using the same setup instructions used by @Frank-Buss above.

Did someone figure out whether HiDrive by Strato is actually the same as HiDrive by IONOS? They are in fact still two different companies and the products are marketed separately, though it is worth to note that both providers are owned nowadays by the same company, i.e. United Internet AG (https://www.united-internet.de/en/).

Anyway, focusing on HiDrive by Strato, while they offer WebDAV access for some of their products that come with an extended "protocol package", the default way of accessing HiDrive is via a REST web API documented here: https://developer.hidrive.com/http-api-reference/
In fact, HiDrive accounts with the protocol package can easily be accessed via FTP, SFTP, rsync or even SMB, all preferable options over WebDAV.

In summary, I believe there is still value in supporting the HiDrive REST API as it offers access without any add-on packages. (Personally, my HiDrive account comes with the protocol package and I use SFTP/sshfs to access my data from my desktop; SSH/SFTP access was actually the primary reason why I signed up for it in the first place.)

100% percent people are interested in the bargain, HiDrive Strato.
I'm fixing that in the title.

OTOH for 4 years since 2017 we have:
- 3 thumbs up on the first post (almost NO demand)
- 0 (ZERO) volunteers

That's probably because FTP/SFTP/Webdav is more than enough.

Let's see in a year... :)
If nobody has even a wish to drop a single line in the docs (this can be pretty quickly done via Github WebUI without any go/git dance), I'll close this out.

issue.title: new backend: STRATO HiDrive - fixes #1069

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?

This adds support for the cloud storage technology HiDrive as a new backend called `hidrive`.
It directly uses the [HiDrive REST API](https://developer.hidrive.com/http-api-reference/), offering access to more features and better usability, as opposed to connecting rclone to HiDrive via webdav, etc.
As the API is the same for [HiDrive by STRATO](https://www.strato.de/cloud-speicher/) and [HiDrive by IONOS](https://www.ionos.de/office-loesungen/hidrive-cloud-speicher), this new backend will work for both.

**The code is written by myself with support from my team here at [STRATO AG](https://www.strato.de/).**

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Yes, see #1069.

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [x] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

-------

We are mostly ready to start the review process for this change,
but there are some last quirks we would like to discuss with you before.

I will also add a few notes to the code in its current state, highlighting some design choices that you may disagree with and thus need to change.

Back to the discussion:

<details>
<summary>This has been resolved.</summary>

#### TestIntegration/FsMkdir/FsPutError

When running `test_all -backends hidrive` there are currently two tests that are failing:
- `TestIntegration/FsMkdir/FsPutError`
- `TestCopyFileMaxTransfer`

Both fail for the same reason, that is highlighted by the comment above `TestFsPutError`:
https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/e43b5ce5e59b5717a9819ff81805dd431f710c10/fstest/fstests/fstests.go#L698-L701
This is not a condition that the API can satisfy for files of arbitrary size.

**TL;DR**: The question is how to proceed?
If it suffices that the tests pass for small files, that change can be made without too much hassle.
If the condition should hold true for files of any size, a system resembling the `Chunker`-backend would be a possible solution.

Specifically files up to 2 GiB can be uploaded using a single request; files larger than this need to be uploaded in multiple parts.
There is no transactional mechanism to upload a file in multiple parts.

Currently the `hidrive`-backend always creates an empty file as a first step, even if the file could be uploaded using a single request.
This is done to simplify the code and program flow, but can easily be changed, which would suffice for the tests to pass successfully. 
But the condition `TestFsPutError` is supposed to test, will still not hold for files of any size, just for smaller ones.

----------------

</details>

#### Symbolic Links

_Note: The following section concerns symbolic links that can be natively stored with HiDrive, not the `.rclonelink`-files that rclone uses to encode and store symbolic links. The `hidrive`-backend will handle `.rclonelink`-files as regular files._

HiDrive can natively store symbolic links (symlinks) and has a special type for them, but they can not be up- or downloaded directly using the API.
In general the operations the API can execute on symlinks directly are limited to:
- delete
- move (+ rename)
- copy

This means that symlinks can not be handled by rclone as regular files.

At the moment the `hidrive`-backend simply ignores any native symlinks on `List(...)`, meaning that users can not interact with existing native symlinks in HiDrive-Accounts using rclone. 
As a consequence, deleting using `rclone delete --rmdirs` will *not* be able to remove directories containing symlinks; they can only be deleted via `rclone purge`.

As noted, the `hidrive`-backend is not able to create native symlinks eitherway, but it still may be confusing for users if they can not interact with existing native symlinks.

The preferred solution would be for backends to be able to support native symlinks directly.

Otherwise, a solution that comes to mind is to implement a special `fs.Object`-type in the `hidrive`-backend, that only supports the 3 API-operations mentioned above.
